Edited May 19, 2016 by WinkAllKerb''

12 hours ago, PB666 said:

I don't think it was exactly the same.

The point they make that is interesting is that in spacetime nonlocality can be deteministic (bohrian-like) and non-deterministic (copenhagen-like) depending on the length of time between the resolution of two entangled events. As we know photons don't age, they don't have mass, so at SoL time stops, but not apparently quantum time. The deterministic wavefunction is ever so slowly tick-tocking. 

It is interesting that the interactions of space-time and qm require a few quantum tick-tock and that quantum jumps allow for distances considerably greater than planks length, the bohrian wavefunctions coukd have dimensions of the universe. 

In the context of the Cannae drive this could allow for things like electron orbitals with dimensions that are huge. 

Edited May 19, 2016 by PB666
